Product: Wireless Headphones, Otium X6 Neckband Bluetooth Headphones...
Reviews:
The Otium X6 was reduced a bit during the Prime Day sale, but it listed all of the qualities of comparible higher-priced bluetooth units, without any unbelievabe claims attached, so I felt it was worth the risk to order a brand I'd never heard of. I am very pleased with the materials and solid construction of this headset. The first unit sent proved to have a glitch in the control button response/funtionality, which unfortunately didn't resolve with extended use. Disclaimer; I haven't used the X6 for taking/making phones calls, since all phone calls do is interupt ones enjoyment of listening to music, sorry). After contacing OtiumDirect, they kindly and promptly provided a replacement X6 headset, which exhibited none of the symptoms of the first unit. The replacement was completely free from glitches and has operatedly flawlessly, so it gets the review. Since other reviewers have added good photos of this unit in their reviews, nothing could be added by duplicating their photography.

The X6 was packed well, in a form fitted plastic insert placed in the outer box, with 3 pair of various sized extra inner ear-tips below the insert, with a USB charging cord, warranty card and tiny manual (too small for me to read). The 'Airwings' hold the earphones in my ear and keep the headphones in the proper direction Although I don't jog or exercise with them, I suspect the 'Airwings' will be useful to those that do. The extra eartips will allow you to have a custom and comfortable fit. After an intial charge, the X6 paired effortlessly with the assistance ofvocal prompts. The magnetic attraction of the earphones keeps them from becoming unduly tangled when you set them aside. In practice, Bluetooth 4.2 definitely seems to have much-improved tonal qualities regardless of volume. The X6 battery life offers around a relistic 4-6 hour playback time, depending on volume used and program/music material. I'm unsure how many button presses for volume and track-changes affects battery life. The audio response of the X6 is amazing, considering it's price, It takes 40-80 hours to break-in a headset, but from the first time they were powered on, I've loved the sound of the X6. I never expected to hear such deep clear bass or crips mid and high range at any volume from a bluetooth set, much less at this price. The reception distance of the X6 is better than other Bluetooth sets I've owned, without any discernable dropout or lag when going from one room to the next. Even with a thin paneled wall between the source and X6, I found no sonic diffence. I've reached listening distances of approximately 35-45 feet from the tablet which should be plenty of range for most users. It doesn't matter which transmission source I use, the X6 receives easily, the exception was an ancient anidroid mini-tablet that kept dropping the signal. I love my closed AKG's for studio use, and my wired SkullCandy takes a close 2nd, but the Otium X6 is now my favorite wireless headset, hands-down. I can't think of a reason to pay more for any similar type of semi-wired/wireless design. Otium also offers completely wireless earpiece models which I'm interested in trying at a future date. Otiumobile.com's website was offline and difficult to reach, but when it was sorted out I was able to properly register the X6 for a longer warranty. The only gripe, was the extremely small lettering in the tiny manual; keep your magnifying glass handy, but at least it was included!

I'm happy to give both the X6 headphones and the distributer, OtiumDirect, an unrestrained 5-Star rating for a great product and for the courteous, prompt customer service thy've provided. I'm not a paid product endorser/reviewer; I always offer my honest opinion. Anyone who enjoys listening to music will enjoy having a set of these headphones, at such a great low price. I hope this review helps fellow Amazonians make good purchasing decisions.

Reviews:
These sound pretty good, and they were surprisingly inexpensive for Bluetooth earphones, and they add some nice features, but because those features override standard behavior, switching between these earphones and normal ones can be a little frustrating.

Most audio programs for mobile platforms have a user-definable function for double-clicking the remote button. You can skip ahead a few seconds to fast-forward through podcast advertisements. You can jump back a few seconds in case you missed something in your audiobook. You can skip to the next track. Etc.

These earphones override that functionality and will only re-dial the last-called number on your phone when you double-click the "MF Button." However, they include a useful feature to rewind or fast-forward a little but by holding down the volume up or down buttons for a few seconds, giving you more flexibility once you get used to the non-standard operation.

Another minor annoyance is that if you pause the audio on your phone for awhile (for example, to finish writing/editing a review for the earphones), the earphones will automatically disconnect and reconnect to your Bluetooth device (e.g. phone) every so often, which is really jarring, because the "Disconnected.. pairing.. connected" voice prompts are quite a bit louder than they should be (that is, they're louder than most audio content you'll be listening to).

The issue with the voice prompt volume being too loud affects all aspects of these earphones - powering on, powering off, pairing, connecting, and disconnecting. They're just too loud and jarring, or when they're not, other content is too quiet.

Reviews:
Check me out at Cboothreviews.wordpress.com for more reviews!

Brand: Otium
Model: X6 Neckband Wireless Headphones

Overall Rating: 4/5 if they work, 1/5 currently.

Introduction:
I love headphones, I absolutely enjoy getting new headphones, trying out new headphones, and talking about headphones. I ordered these headphones along with another pair of Otium headphones and was fortunately able to try out both at the same time. Up until recently, these were my favorite pair of headphones. They currently, however, will not charge and so I cannot use them. It may be the cable I have to charge them, I will update this if trying a different cable helps.

Product Description:
These are Bluetooth headphones that consist of two earbuds wired to a necklace-like device that rests around your neck. The earbuds themselves have no buttons on them but there are three buttons on the right side of the necklace: volume down, a utility button, and volume up.

The length of the earbud cord from the necklace is plenty long enough to be comfortable while not being too long and awkward. The necklace is great if you are just listening in one ear as the other headphone will hang without dragging that ear out. Often Bluetooth headphones consist of two earbuds attached only via a cord, like Beats' popular model. While these are stylish, they are absolutely frustrating when using one headphone at a time as the non-used headphone will literally drag the other one out of your ear. For most people this isn't an issue as they are perfectly content ignoring the rest of the world, so two ears is fine with them. I like hearing people/sounds as I'm listening so unless I'm alone studying/reading I typically only use 1 ear at a time.

One more nice feature is that the volume down button is the first (and therefore easiest) button so that if the music is suddenly too loud you can quickly alleviate that.

The earbuds also have small rubber flaps designed to help them stay in your ear better. These are actually quite useful and, unlike some other headphones I've used, they actually stay on decently well. If the flaps bother you they are easily removable (or re-attachable if you change your mind) as you just slide the rubber ring on/off.

The headphones come with three different sizes of grips, but they are not very high quality grips. They work fine, don't get me wrong, but they're just the standard quality rubber.

Finally, the earbuds can magnetically stick together, which is semi-useful if you're wearing the headphones but not using them. By sticking them together they don't fly around as much.

Product Features
The headphones can easily connect via Bluetooth to my phone and laptop, at the same time if desired, and likely to additional devices. The necklace can adjust the volume by pressing the volume up/down buttons or change tracks by holding the volume up/down buttons. Power is controlled by holding the middle utility button, holding it turns them on/off. Pressing it once without holding pauses/resumes the music. Overall, most standard music controls can be achieved via the necklace without even looking at your phone/device.

In terms of sound quality, these are among the best cheap headphones I've ever used, and I've had about 20 pairs of headphones. In fact, until they stopped working these were my favorite pair to use. I even brought them to Kauai with me. I did, however, say these are among the best "cheap" headphones. My favorite pair of headphones was an old pair of Sony headphones called "Extra Bass headphones". They cost about $60, sounded beautiful, and the bass vibrated from them so well. These cost about $24 currently ($90 originally), but I would be willing to pay about $30 for them. They sound great but their range is not as wide as the Sony ones, they have great deep bass but not quite those of the Sony headphones or the other Otium ones, and they seal out sound well but again, not quite as well as the Sony ones.

In terms of battery life (before they stopped charging on me), they lasted about 2-3 hours or so. Honestly not the greatest battery for me, but they worked well enough and charge quickly enough that it wasn't a huge issue. The low battery life and poor quality grips were the main reasons I would give them a 4/5.

Pros:
Necklace with many controls easily-accessible.
Phenomenal sound for the price I paid.
Earbuds designed to stay in ear.
Earbuds can clip together to prevent flying around.
Easy Bluetooth connectivity to multiple devices.
Decent sound cancellation.

Cons:
Not as powerful or clear as higher-end headphones.
Grips provided with headphones are average-quality.
They stopped working on me.
Conclusion:
Great-quality headphones for the price until they stopped retaining battery charge.

Update!!!
I contacted the seller, explained the issue about the battery charge, and they sent me a new replacement free of charge. This new pair holds a charge much better than the initial ones, so I bringing my review back up to 4/5.

I primarily listen to Podcasts, and audio books, not music, so I won't judge the sound quality other than to say the spoken word sounds very good. The earbuds have little "arms" that help hold them in your ears. When working under a car or RV these are light enough that they don't tend to fall off as easily as others I have used. Plus they the ear pieces are held together magnetically if not in your ears. Therefore, when they have fallen off my neck while laying on the ground, they have stayed with me. I lost one pair of the other style when they fell off while working on an RV at a camp ground and did not remember that I had them on. I have used these for a number of phone conversations and have had no complaints that the person on the other end could not hear me.
The only negative that I have thus far is they don't tell you the battery level when you power them on. I forgot to charge them for 3 or 4 days and ran out of battery.
